description.plain: Cornell Iral Haynes, Jr. (born November 2, 1974), known professionally as Nelly, is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, entrepreneur, investor, and occasional actor from St. Louis, Missouri. Nelly embarked on his music career with Midwest hip hop group St. Lunatics, in 1993 and signed to Universal Records in 1999. Under Universal, Nelly began his solo career in the year 2000, with his debut album Country Grammar, of which the title-track was a top ten hit. The album debuted at number three on the Billboard 200 and went on to peak at number one. Country Grammar is Nelly’s best-selling album to date, selling over 8.4 million copies in the United States. His following album Nellyville, produced the number-one hits “Hot in Herre” and Dilemma. Other singles included “Work It”, “Air Force Ones”, “Pimp Juice” and “#1”.

songs.title: Dilemma

description.plain:
A hugely popular song from 2002 which appeared on both Nelly’s Nellyville and Kelly Rowland’s Simply Deep.

This song is arguably the most successful, ‘biggest’ song of both Nelly’s career and Rowland’s solo career (aside from her featured vocals in David Guetta’s “When Love Takes Over”).

It was Nelly’s first #1 single in countries such as the UK, Ireland, Australia, Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands. It followed on from the success of his previous single “Hot in Herre”.

It was – and remains to be – Rowland’s highest selling single in the US and the UK, as it has sold over 935,000 copies as of November 2017.

songs.title: The Fix

description.plain:
Nelly teams up with Jeremih, hitmaker DJ Mustard, and Mike Free to put a new spin on Marvin Gaye’s “Sexual Healing.”

Nelly explained on “The Breakfast Club” that he and DJ Mustard share a publisher, who went to work before the song’s release to make sure their interpolations of Gaye were all cleared before the song came out.

“The Fix” is the first single from Nelly’s upcoming album.

songs.title: Country Grammar (Hot Shit)

description.plain:
The very first single Nelly ever released, and proof he was primed for commercial success. The song is produced by Epperson, and see’s Nelly debuting his wildly popular mesh of singing and rapping. The track is simply about his St. Louis hometown, and how he flexes through the city on a regular basis.

The chorus is an interpolation of the “Down Down Baby” clapping game. The music video adheres to the hip-hop tropes: expensive cars, beautiful women, oversized clothes, and the entire neighbourhood backing him up.

He arrived on the charts that day in February 2000. It shot to number 1 on the US Hot Rap Songs, and began a life long love affair with the international market, charting in Australia, Austria, Netherlands, Canada, New Zealand, Sweden, the UK and Switzerland.

songs.full_title: Get Like Me by Nelly (Ft. Nicki Minaj & Pharrell Williams)
songs.title: Get Like Me
songs.title_with_featured: Get Like Me (Ft. Nicki Minaj & Pharrell Williams)

description.plain:
Nelly links up with Nicki Minaj and Pharrell Williams on his single “Get Like Me,” also produced by Pharrell. The drum-patterned track, reminiscent of a classic Neptunes production, was released as the first cut from Nelly’s 2013 album “M.O.”

Nelly talks slick over the thumping beat, Nicki keeps the momentum going, adding a playful verse, and Pharrell adds his golden touch to the hook, singing in his raspy voice.

Originally the track just featured Nelly and Pharrell and the St. Lunatic sat on it for a year before he had a brainwave. “We were coming back to the records that we did, closing out the album and putting everything together and I was just like, ‘Yo I think Nicki might be dope on this,’” Nelly told MTV News “We made it happen and I was right. She killed it!”

songs.title: Just a Dream

description.plain: This song is Nelly talking about the love of his life that left him. The “love” and relationship that they had together were really fake and just a dream–Like when you have a really good dream (possibly related to someone you’re crushing on) and the feeling you get when you wake up and find out it was “just a dream.”

songs.title: E.I.

description.plain: This is the no. 8 track on his album Country Grammar that dropped wayback 2000. “E.I.” Stands for “Eat it”, Nelly uses it often in his songs. Means that you are about to receive oral sex. But later on, Nelly explain to the rap fans and the nation to a St. Louis slang. “E.I. means “Yes! Bring it on!’” he explained at nelly.net.

description.plain:
The song “Grillz” was released at the apex of the mainstream success the Houston rap scene’s success. Arguably popularized by Paul Wall who along with TV Johnny run a custom grill shop in Houston, Texas.

In 2012 grillz made another appearance in popular culture when Olympic gold medal swimmer Ryan Lochte sported a custom grill on the international stage.

Nelly’s flow and some of his lyrics on this song are lifted from “Kanday” by LL Cool J.

songs.full_title: Air Force Ones by Nelly (Ft. Ali Jones, Kyjuan & Murphy Lee)
songs.title: Air Force Ones
songs.title_with_featured: Air Force Ones (Ft. Ali Jones, Kyjuan & Murphy Lee)

description.plain:
A tribute to the classic Nike Air Force 1 shoe, and a wildly successful single for Nelly that reached number 3 on the US Billboard 100. The music video is a classic, featuring Nelly and his St. Lunatics crew purchasing a variety of colours, shapes, and sizes.

The track seemed to solidify Nelly as somewhat of an expert on the shoe, so much so people now  seek him out to talk about the shoe.

songs.full_title: Over and Over by Nelly (Ft. Tim McGraw)
songs.title: Over and Over

description.plain:
“Over and Over” is a song by American rapper Nelly featuring American country music singer Tim McGraw, released as the second single from his fourth album Suit.

The song talks about their breakups with the girl they love and how they can’t stop thinking about her. They can’t bare to see her with any other man.

songs.title: My Place

description.plain:
“My Place” is the first single from Nelly’s 2004 album, “Suit”. It reached Number 4 on the American Billboard Charts and was very popular in the British Commonwealth, reaching Number 1 in the United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand.

In the song, Nelly, with the help of Jaheim, tries to win back a former girlfriend of his that left him, apologizing for any past transgressions, and asking her to come over to “my place”.

The song came out a few months before the album and samples Teddy Pendergrass' “Come Go With Me”, and halfway through the song, it has a small sample of DeBarge’s song “I Like It” while the overall song features a sample of Labelle’s 1977 hit, “Isn’t It a Shame”.

description.plain:
“Stepped on My J'z” is a track off of Nelly’s 2008 album, Brass Knuckles. Its central theme is the importance of his Air Jordan’s (a.k.a. his J'z), specifically discussing the biggest tragedy of all for any sneakerhead: having someone scuff them up.



Music Video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oohCQPABS7I

description.plain:
Nelly comes back once again with a soulful single which appreciates the lady he has. He speaks of how amazing the lady he has made him happy and that she is better than most of the joys we find appealing in life.
It will definitely touch your heart somewhere after the first few lines.

description.plain:
This song gained most of it’s attention from its highly controversial, sexually explicit video.

“It’s actually not clear who this is demeaning the most; women, black people in general, or me, the viewer. Haven’t seen that much money being mindlessly thrown at a shuddering arse since CNN hired Piers Morgan” – Charlie Brooker on watching the video.

songs.title: Greed, Hate, Envy

description.plain: ‘Greed, Hate, Envy’ was released on the two thousand album, ‘Country Grammer’ and lasted four minutes and fifteen seconds. It was produced by Saint Lunatics' member, Lavell Webb, who was signed to Derrty Entertainment and Universal Studios. It’s album debuted at number three on the US Billboard 200 chart, and went on to peak at number one with two hundred and thirty five thousand copies in it’s first week of sales

songs.title: Fly Away

description.plain:
Fly Away is a song relating to prison inmates desires who want to be free from prison and wishing to get out. This song can also be interpreted in different ways, such as a young brother who is in a rut in their life and wants to get away from the problems that had occurred or a boy who is now turning from an adolescent to an adult and has many problems approaching and coming his way that he knows he has to face.

There are many, many interpretations that can be made for this song, it just all depends on what the listener is going through at the moment.

Nelly’s best song, if not, definitely one of his best.

songs.title: Nellyville

description.plain: Nellyville, the title track and intro track of Nelly’s 2002 album, takes us into a journey of the eponymous Nellyville, a utopia imagined by none other than Nelly himself. Here, the sun is alway shining, the birds are always singing, and everything is nice and serene.

Ain't nobody snitchin, they refuse to say

And if we vote it rains - know how wet we want it to be

You do unto others if you don't want it don't do the cappin
Think that's cool? 40 acres and a mule
Fuck that! Nellyville - 40 acres and a pool
Six bedrooms, full bath with a jacuzz'
Six-car garage, pavement smooth
Both front and back deck 'nough room to land a jet

[Hook]

[Nelly] Everybody, uh, now everybody say

I need to go - down to Nellyville

Yeah
There's no.. way.. yeah

[Nelly]
I remember February 27, 1994
Tryin to make it to the hospital through three inches of snow (hey)

songs.title: N’ Dey Say

description.plain:
This is the 6th track that appears on Suit, the 4th studio album by american rapper Nelly.
Suit was intended to be released on August 17, 2004, before being delayed and released on September 13, 2004, by Universal Records.

The sample used for the beat is Spandau Ballet- True
